content: This is really hard... Also your visualisation link no longer works, so it's hard to understand now too (https://xorzy.github.io/coc/airplane).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I thought this was great -- the problem statement is clear and playing with it was smooth.

Caveat: I expect that a large fraction (70%?) of Clash participants won't finish this one in time. (Presumably we want only a small proportion of Clash puzzles to be this hard.) I do think that it could in theory be done in <5min but expect very few users will manage that. (I'd be open to feedback on whether this is a reasonable interpretation of or exception to the 'solvable in 5 minutes' rule.)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a challenging but really fun problem.
This is relatively hard, but FUN!
I agree that this is a tough challenge to do in minimal code size and will push many people to just get it done in time.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: C'est une très bonne contribution
pas très difficile ni très facile
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

personally i'm not sure if it's a good one for "shortest" clash... it will surely be a good practice without timing to me (maybe with additional rule of  1,1 > crash 2,1<)

but anyway a cool clash!
very interesting clash!

Very interesting clash. Definitely not like one of trivial ones, where you compete in speed or reading/typing. It took me slightly more that 15 minutes to code and test. I lost some time on debugging, because I was counting crushed plains not collisions.

Good Clash, but I managed to pass all the validation tests with a wrong code which only fails on "Final test" because I was counting twice some collisions because more than 3 planes were  involved.
So it seems this point is not check in the Validation tests.
Is there a need to introduce the variable t to measure turns/steps if the problem only has one turn?
A very interesting problem, not to easy not too hard, and it's also not monotonous, it kind of reminds me of an arcade video game. Keep it up :D

Very cool puzzle! I think that this kind of puzzle is very doable in 15 minutes (I only needed about 7 minutes. (Without solving the problem codingame has with it's C language... but that's not part of the puzzle))
As Allis stated a couple of days ago, the directions '<' and '^' don't really change the puzzle because you have clearly defined the size "of the space you are monitoring" and explained handling of negative coordinates. The handling of collisions is not influenced by differently moving planes, so I think that four directions don't make anything more difficult. (I'd even say it's more interesting ;) )

Another thing (C_Boy mentioned this): I also would appreciate some more test cases for the additional directions, even though I personally wouldn't need them. BUT, others might need a very simple example with planes flying in four different directions. (So if you decide on using four directions, you might consider changing your first example to an example with four directions)

Nice. 

May I suggest you introduce "t=0" as "turn, t=0" in first occurrence as it wasn't clear what t=0 was on first read - I thought it was a time/r.
You might need to describe the next N lines as next t lines if each one is a turn in the game as N is used for number of planes at turn zero?

If you have introduced the < ^ directions then an easier test case that include these would be useful to players.
Really nice! I don't think the addition of '<' and '^' make the problem too difficult; you very clearly indicate how to handle negatives without spelling it out.
Thanks for the input :)

Thank you for your feedback!
I have modified the statement to clarify what t=0 means.
Regarding the N input lines, they all represent the state of a given airplane at t=0, not the position of planes over time so I think naming them T instead of N would increase confusion.
As for the additional directions I'll consider adding more test cases if I get more feedback on whether or not they make the puzzle harder to solve (not always easy to judge when you code the solution to your own puzzle :p).
But again: A very interesting and unique puzzle. I enjoyed solving it! :)
Thanks!
The problem does not have only one turn. It has many in fact. You do not have to keep track of t indeed, but it's there so one can understand this is a step-by-step simulation problem.

Thank you for your input!
Would it possible to see your code to see exactly what when wrong and either modify or add a test case?
Thanks!
Thanks for the feedback!
Thanks for the input!

Thank you for your feedback!
Well this definitely won't be one of these problems you can solve in just 16 chars but I think that, if anything, shortest mode also provides a way to approach a puzzle without worrying as much about the timer.
I'm sorry but I did not understand your other suggestion, could you please rephrase it? Thanks!
Thank you!
Thanks!

Thank you!
This is indeed not a trivial problem, although it is not a very difficult puzzle either in the sense that it can be simulated in a relatively straightforward way, with only what I think are basic programming skills, like array manipulations and 2d coordinates. The difficulty is probably more in how to implement a solution in a timely manner, but I think it is important to have clashes of various difficulty levels since the community of clash participants is varied in programming experience as well.

the code with problems, I've add comments for the right code:

w = int(input())
h = int(input())
pl = {}

n = int(input())
for i in range(n):
    inputs = input().split()
    x = int(inputs[0])
    y = int(inputs[1])
    c = inputs[2]
    pl[x,y] = c
col=0

mv= {'<':(-1,0),'>':(1,0),'v':(0,1),'^':(0,-1)}
#proper in comments
while pl:
    nt = {} #; rem = set()
    for p,d in pl.items():
        dx,dy = mv[d]; x, y = p
        np = (x+dx,y+dy);
        inas = 0<=x+dx<w and 0<=y+dy<h
        if np in nt:col += 1; del(nt[np])
        #if np in nt:rem.add(np)
        elif inas: nt[np]=d        
    #col+=len(rem)
    #for p in rem:del(nt[p])    
    pl=nt
print(col)

Thank you, I have added a test case to check especially for that bug.
I have also made Validator 11 more consistent.
Thanks!
I'm still not following how there is more than one timestep. It seems that every plane only ever moves once.

Perhaps you should look at the solution?
It might help you understand better what's going on.

Thanks for the very thorough review!
Yeah now that I got some feedback on the additional directions I will add a few test cases tomorrow ;)
I tested it and, possibly my coding, but I tripped up with the validator for chained reaction.  Should be possible in time with all directions.
